An eg for bride
 wealth 
 
 Nambi Ssepuya Comunity
 Resource Centre
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Once upon a time, there was an old
 woman who loved her grandson very
 much. 
 
 She gave him an eg as a gift. 
 She said, “From this eg you wil get
 bride wealth for your mariage when you
 
 are of age.” 
 And the boy went on his way. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 First he met some blackbery gatherers 
 
 who asked him for the eg. 
 They used it to shot at the beries and it 
 broke. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The boy cried, 
 “Ei…Ei…Ei! You have caused trouble for
 me! 
 
 The eg was not mine. 
 It belonged to my grandmother. 
 And grandmother didn’t give it to me for
 
 nothing. 
 She gave it to me to get bride wealth.”
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 So the bery gatherers gave him the stick 
 they used to bring down the beries. 
 
 And the boy walked on. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Next the boy met some builders who
 
 asked him for his stick. 
 They used it to build a house and it broke
 into pieces. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The boy cried, 
 
 “He…He…He! You have caused 
 trouble for me! The stick was not mine, it 
 
 belonged to the bery gatherers. 
 And they didn’t give it to me for nothing. 
 They gave it to me in place of my eg. 
 
 The eg was not mine. 
 It belonged to my grandmother. 
 
 And grandmother didn’t give it to me for 
 nothing, 
 She gave it to me to get bride wealth.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 So the builders gave him a bundle of
 gras for thatching. 
 
 And the boy walked on. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Next the boy found a herdsman who 
 
 asked for the boy’s bundle of gras. 
 The herdsman gave it to the cow and the 
 cow ate it al up. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 The boy cried, “E…E…E! You have caused
 
 trouble for me! The gras was not mine.
 It belonged to the builders. 
 
 The builders did not give it to me for
 nothing. They broke my stick. 
 The stick was not mine. It belonged to
 
 the bery gatherers. 
 And they didn’t give it to me for nothing.
 They gave it to me in place of my eg.
 
 The eg was not mine. It belonged to my
 grandmother. 
 
 And grandmother did not give it to me for
 nothing. 
 She gave it to me to get bride wealth.”
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 So the herdsman gave the boy his cow. 
 And the boy walked on. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 While on his way home, the boy came
 acros a mariage celebration. 
 The bride’s family asked him for his cow.
 
 He gave it to them. 
 And they slaughtered it and ate it al.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 The boy cried, “Ei…Ei…Ei! You have 
 caused trouble for me! The cow was not 
 mine. It belonged to the herdsman. 
 
 The herdsman didn’t give it to me for 
 nothing. He gave it to me in place of my 
 
 bundle of gras. 
 The gras was not mine. It belonged to 
 the builders. 
 
 The builders didn’t give it to me for 
 nothing. They broke my stick. 
 The stick was not mine. It belonged to 
 
 the bery gatherers. 
 They didn’t give it to me for nothing. They 
 
 gave it to me in place of my eg. 
 The eg was not mine. It belonged to my 
 grandmother. And grandmother didn’t 
 
 give it to me for nothing, 
 She gave it to me to get bride wealth.” 
 
 
 12  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Then the bride’s family said, “We have
 nothing left to pay you. But let us give
 
 you the bride.” 
 
 And so, the saying came to pas that,
 
 “What goes round comes around!”
